conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to understand the forces acting on each block and how they relate to the acceleration of the blocks.

The force F applied to block B causes it to accelerate. The acceleration of block B is a. According to Newton's second law, the net force acting on block B is equal to the mass of block B times its acceleration. Therefore, the force F is equal to m_B × a.

Block C is connected to block B by a light spring. When block B accelerates, the spring will stretch, causing block C to accelerate as well. The acceleration of block C is a. According to Newton's second law, the net force acting on block C is equal to the mass of block C times its acceleration. Therefore, the force F is equal to m_C × a.

Block D is not connected to block B or C. The only force acting on block D is the frictional force f that opposes its motion. The acceleration of block D is a. According to Newton's second law, the net force acting on block D is equal to the mass of block D times its acceleration. Therefore, the frictional force f is equal to m_D × a.

The static friction force f is the minimum force that opposes the motion of block D. Since block D is not accelerating, the frictional force f is equal to the static friction force f_s. Therefore, f_s = m_D × a.
The acceleration of the blocks is a. Since the blocks are accelerating together with the same acceleration, the acceleration of block D is also a.
The frictional force f is equal to the static friction force f_s. Therefore, f = f_s = m_D × a.
The magnitude of the static friction force acting on block D during the acceleration process is m_D × a.
